Inference: Water usage dropping sharply during rain detections and low temperatures indicates efficient rainfall-driven irrigation suppression
Description: Cool, rainy conditions reduce irrigation demand entirely, allowing the system to save water.
short rationale: Rain covers demand; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage dropping sharply during rain detections and rising humidity indicates strong storm moisture coverage
Description: Rainfall and high humidity together reduce the need for irrigation almost immediately.
short rationale: Storm moisture suppresses irrigation; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage remaining high during rain detections despite falling temperatures indicates delayed irrigation shutdown
Description: The irrigation system may not be responding quickly enough to rainfall events.
short rationale: Highlights control misalignment despite rain; moderate operational concern.

Inference: Water usage rising during long gaps without rain detections and high temperatures indicates heat-driven irrigation demand
Description: Hot, dry periods force water usage to increase to counter evapotranspiration losses.
short rationale: Heat-driven demand; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage rising during long gaps without rain detections and falling humidity indicates atmospheric drying conditions
Description: Dry air accelerates moisture loss, triggering increased irrigation use.
short rationale: Dry-air driven usage; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling during long gaps without rain detections and rising humidity suggests natural atmospheric moisture compensating for irrigation need
Description: Humidity reduces evaporative stress, lowering irrigation requirements.
short rationale: Atmospheric moisture easing demand; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage stable during volatile temperature and humidity conditions with no rain detections indicates schedule-driven irrigation
Description: Environmental fluctuations do not influence irrigation output.
short rationale: Schedule-driven behavior; modest operational insight.

Inference: Water usage rising during high temperature and high humidity with no rain detections suggests tropical evapotranspiration stress
Description: Heat and humidity cannot offset moisture demand, requiring substantial irrigation.
short rationale: Tropical-like stress driving usage; low privacy impact.

Inference: Water usage falling during low temperature and high humidity with no rain detections indicates natural moisture retention
Description: Cool, moist conditions reduce soil drying, lowering irrigation usage.
short rationale: Natural retention reducing use; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising during low humidity and stable temperatures indicates atmospheric dryness is the primary driver
Description: Dry air increases evaporation even without temperature changes.
short rationale: Humidity-driven dryness; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising during rain detections and high temperatures indicates rainfall insufficient to offset thermal drying
Description: Heat evaporates rainfall faster than it can hydrate soil, forcing irrigation to assist.
short rationale: Rain insufficient under heat; modest operational context.

Inference: Water usage rising during rain detections and low humidity indicates warm rainfall with evaporative loss
Description: Rain may evaporate before providing meaningful soil hydration.
short rationale: Warm-rain evaporation causing extra use; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling to near-zero during heavy rain detections and low temperatures indicates rainfall fully meeting irrigation demand
Description: The system shuts off watering because natural rainfall is adequate.
short rationale: Rain fully replaces irrigation; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling to near-zero during multiple rain detections and high humidity indicates prolonged wet conditions
Description: Sustained rainfall and humid air eliminate irrigation need across cycles.
short rationale: Prolonged wet period; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising after rain detections and high temperatures indicates rapid post-rain evaporation
Description: Heat causes moisture loss quickly after rain, forcing irrigation to resume.
short rationale: Post-rain heat driving usage; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising after rain detections despite high humidity indicates shallow rainfall penetration
Description: Humidity spikes, but soil moisture does not improve enough, requiring irrigation.
short rationale: Shallow rain prompts irrigation; modest operational detail.

Inference: Water usage falling after rain detections and stable temperatures indicates residual soil saturation
Description: Rainfall leaves the soil wet enough to reduce irrigation for a time.
short rationale: Residual saturation reducing use; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage stable during alternating rain detections and temperature swings indicates irrigation system insensitivity
Description: Environmental events do not significantly influence irrigation volume.
short rationale: Insensitive irrigation behavior; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage rising at night during low temperatures with no rain detections indicates misaligned or schedule-based irrigation
Description: Nighttime conditions usually require less water, but system configuration may ignore this.
short rationale: Flags misaligned/night overwatering; moderate operational concern.

Inference: Water usage falling at night during high humidity and rain detections indicates optimal irrigation reduction
Description: Nighttime rainfall and humidity reduce the need for watering.
short rationale: Appropriate night cutbacks; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising sharply during midday temperature spikes and no rain detections indicates diurnal irrigation response
Description: High midday heat accelerates moisture loss, triggering irrigation boosts.
short rationale: Midday heat response; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage falling during early-morning humidity peaks and rain detections suggests dew and rainfall together hydrate soil
Description: Natural atmospheric moisture reduces irrigation demand at dawn.
short rationale: Dawn moisture lowering use; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage rising despite rain detections and weather cooling indicates severe soil dryness
Description: Rainfall and temperature drops cannot compensate for deep soil moisture deficits.
short rationale: Deep dryness driving use despite rain; moderate concern.

Inference: Water usage falling despite no rain detections and rising temperatures indicates irrigation throttling or system malfunction
Description: The system fails to deliver appropriate irrigation during heating periods.
short rationale: Potential malfunction under heat; moderate operational risk.

Inference: Water usage rising when humidity falls sharply but no rain is detected indicates atmospheric-driven soil drying
Description: Low humidity increases evaporative loss, requiring higher irrigation.
short rationale: Dry-air driven usage increases; low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage falling when humidity rises without rain detections suggests atmospheric moisture is easing irrigation demand
Description: Humidity alone can reduce drying, allowing reduced irrigation.
short rationale: Humidity easing demand; very low sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage fluctuating strongly during intermittent rain detections and temperature swings indicates unstable weather patterns
Description: Irrigation must adjust frequently to unpredictable environmental conditions.
short rationale: Unstable weather drives adjustments; low privacy risk.

Inference: Water usage stabilizing at low levels during long rain detection periods despite temperature variation indicates rainfall-dominant water supply
Description: Rainfall consistently meets soil moisture needs regardless of temperature.
short rationale: Rain-dominant supply; minimal sensitivity.

Inference: Water usage stabilizing at high levels during long periods with no rain detections and falling humidity indicates sustained drought
Description: Persistent atmospheric dryness requires constant irrigation.
short rationale: Sustained drought keeping usage high; moderate operational impact.

Inference: Water usage rising during rain detections and humidity rises indicates false rain detection or mist/light drizzle insufficient to offset moisture demand
Description: Sensors detect rain, but not enough water reaches the soil.
short rationale: False/weak rain signals driving extra use; modest sensitivity.
